Description: Body sherd of Chian Simple Animal Style pottery chalice; white slip; interior glazed streaky black; traces of three faded added white lines; exterior: painted decoration consisting of sphinx (part of wing and torso with added red blob remaining) to right.
Curator's comments: The sherd joins British Museum 1924,1201.393. Lemos states that the sphinx is standing to left, but the curvature of the wing indicates that it is facing the opposite direction. Furthermore, the angle of the underbelly suggests that the sphinx is seated rather than standing. Sphinxes depicted on Simple Animal Style vases are usually facing left. Those facing right are probably part of an antithetical composition of confronting sphinxes. If this sherd is part of an antithetical composition, then the vessel should belong in the Group of Antithetical Sphinxes. Sherds in this group are stylistically early.
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 290, no. 879)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.1011) (phase 2)
